file_content.text: Prepare the ship to launch. We're leaving.
Analyzing jump trajectories.
Yeah, 'cause us hicks can't use a navicomputer.
How'd the meeting go? You get vacation? Jail time? Both?
How was your meeting? Is everything alright?
Everything alright with the Minister? He sounded serious.
I saw the Minister's expression. How was your meeting?
Imperial Intelligence is gone, and Cipher Nine is dead. From now on, we choose our own fate.
We're finally free.
Oh, you're making me very happy.
We never thought we'd hear that.
You don't cease to surprise me. Patching through a message, if you don't mind.
Imperial Intelligence is gone, and good riddance. The new Empire belongs to us.
I'm rising in the ranks.
Fascinating. Then tonight, we'll drink to progress.
I'm glad we did our duty, sir.
To progress. Yes.
Imperial Intelligence has fallen, but it doesn't change our duty. We soldier on.
We'll keep doing our jobs.
Dedication. One thing Imperials and Killiks have in common.
I think it's inspiring, sir.
Did we imply otherwise?
Pretty thought. So--business as usual.
After everything we've been through, I understand if some of you are tired. But the galaxy is only getting more dangerous.
Anyone with doubts, speak up.
If anyone has doubts--in me or our mission--speak now.
This is our place. We intend to remain.
No one doubts your leadership, sir.
Not like I have other plans.
I'm not finished with you.
And I, as always, am your humble servant.
See? Everyone likes you.
Patching in a message; one moment.
My meeting was confidential, and your jobs haven't changed. You work for me, you work for the good of the Empire. Is that clear?
It doesn't matter for you.
Crystal.
We won't fail you.
Sir!
Straightforward as always. Patching through a message, if you don't mind.
This is command ship Tenebrous, sir. The Sith will want to know--what do you plan to do while we sort things out?
This is command ship Tenebrous. I thought I'd see you off properly; it might be a while before we do this again.
Secure transmission acknowledged, Keeper.
Then let's do this formally.
Keeper was director of Operations. My name is Shara.
Somehow, I doubt it'll be that long. But I appreciate the thought.
We'll see each other again.
There's room aboard the ship. Join me.
Why don't you come with me?
I can't, not with everything that's going on, but... my name is Shara. I'll find you.
Ready to jump to lightspeed.
Yes, apologies. For the record--what are you planning while we sort things here?
I'm about a minute from the jump to lightspeed. Make it fast.
Did you call for a reason?
We're getting questions from Dromund Kaas, and I was hoping to set the record straight:
What's your plan while we sort things out here?
For the record? Better not to ask. But my people and I will be watching, and you'll hear from us again.
You'll find out soon.
I'm going to find threats to the Empire, and I'm going to stop them. Isn't that what we do?
Let's go where we're needed.
Perhaps it is. Tenebrous out.
I'm going to identify those who threaten the Empire--and one by one, you'll see them disappear.
Time to strike at our enemies.
Understood. Good luck.
There's a whole galaxy out there. Who do we lie to next...?
The song ends. The song begins.
People are never going to know what we've done. I think I like that...
Well, then. The great game continues....
Hey! You all catch the show? 'Cause we messed them up!
If they gave medals for unsanctioned operations, sir, you'd be at the top of the list.
An excellent sentiment.
It seems word of our victory precedes us.
I'll start investigating potential leaks.
Cipher--I was able to monitor your life signs after we lost contact.
I'm glad you're still alive--and I'm glad you won.
Hunter is dead, and the inner circle is broken. The Star Cabal has been decimated.
Mission accomplished.
One last victory for Imperial Intelligence.
You could sound happier. Victories like this don't come around often.
Time to cheer!
I know. I'm exhausted, and there's a lot of cleanup to be done--but you do deserve to celebrate.
Self-admiration can wait. Keeper, I need you with the technical team. Cipher, with me, please.
Victories like this don't come along often.
I'm glad, too. [Kiss her]
We should celebrate.
Don't. You've moved on, and I--I....
Step away, mistress.
Yeah, go stutter at the med-bot.
Yes, why don't you both step away?
Blast you both.
We're in public--but I suppose neither of us works for Operations anymore. At least for a little while.
Our personal lives can wait. Keeper, I need you with the technical team. Cipher, with me, please.
I'll see you later. Fixer...?
Duty first. I'll see you later.
Is there a chance someone came aboard the station after I did?
Did you see anyone follow me?
The Dark Council sent a ship to investigate after I broadcast our target list. I don't know if it reached the station intact--the scanners were picking up shadows.
As the fighting wrapped up, Sith reinforcements arrived. They didn't make it back.
The Sith followed me aboard.
They came to investigate after I broadcast our target list. We warned them of the danger.
As the fighting wrapped up, a group of Sith arrived. Did you expect that?
The Sith followed me aboard.
Lord Jadus hadn't informed us of that part of the plan, and we didn't pick them up until the comms were jammed.
The Dark Council sent a ship to investigate after I broadcast our target list. They refused to hold position.
The post-mortem can wait. Keeper, I need you with the technical team. Cipher, with me, please.
You call us, we'll come shooting.
We'll keep an eye on things here. Go.
Give the man my regards. I'll make sure you don't miss anything.
I received word from Lord Ilikith. You delivered the conspirators' secrets to Darth Jadus.
He made me his Hand, and I swore to serve him.
It was my duty.
I received word from the Dark Council. You delivered the conspirators' secrets to the Sith.
We swore to serve the Emperor. I could do nothing less.
It was my duty.
To refuse would have been treason. Or have you forgotten that?
I didn't have much choice.
Count your crimes in the line of duty. I think you'll find you've committed treason before.
But for better or worse, you've ensured that the Empire will continue on its course.
The Sith are not the enemy--petty men hiding behind titles, however, have weakened the Empire for too long.
Unlike you, I don't fear Sith.
Well, if you believe our lords are guiding us in the right direction, I assure you--you've helped the Empire continue on its course.
The Sith will be pleased. Imperial Intelligence will not be rebuilt, and women like you will head its successor. Your due reward.
The Sith will be pleased. Imperial Intelligence will not be rebuilt, and men like you will head its successor. Your due reward.
What do you mean, "Intelligence won't be rebuilt"?
What are you talking about?
The Star Cabal gave the Sith an excuse to cannibalize us. Why would they give power back now?
Sir, listen to yourself. This isn't wise.
Please watch what you say.
No. But it hardly matters anymore.
Lord Jadus promised that species wouldn't matter in the new Empire. He kept his word.
It's time an alien won respect.
Species won't matter, no. Nor will much else.
Perhaps the ruling powers are ready to acknowledge that my people are as capable as yours.
It's time an alien won respect.
Yes, you've struck a blow for the Ascendancy.
I think a reward like that would suit me.
I could use a promotion.
There's already talk of your place in the new world of Sith Intelligence--head of a slate of black projects, with the conspirators' secrets as your weapons.
May the Emperor help you, because I no longer can, Cipher--or whatever you'll be called.
Things will change. But the Star Cabal is gone; for the first time in a thousand years, we're free to determine our own future.
I'll protect the Empire.
And I'll see that no enemy, Republic or otherwise, ever destroys the Sith Empire.
You're still Minister of Intelligence. You expect that to change?
What will happen to you?
With luck, I may retire gracefully. Without, I expect to be hanged.
So it goes with all great servants of the Empire.
You may be right, but I aspire to something else.
We'll see about that.
Goodbye, Minister. If they hang you, not everyone will forget your legacy.
For what it's worth, I never intended this. I'll try to live up to your example.
I'm sorry, sir.
I expect you to try harder than that.
I've had enough speeches for one day. And I don't think I need to listen to you anymore.
You're boring me, Minister.
No. I suppose you don't.
Under your watch, Kaas City was struck by terrorists, I was reprogrammed and Operations was disbanded. I can do without your help.
Power in my hands at last.
Now you'll see what we can do with Sith as allies. No bureaucrats, no Star Cabal--things will change.
Then be ready. You're going to see dark times.
Congratulations are due, but the surviving conspirators are going to ground. Did you recover their data?
I found the Black Codex, and I destroyed it.
I wiped the Cabal's secrets.
You what? Do you know what you've unleashed?
The conspirators' weapons and resources aren't going to disappear, and we can't guess who'll obtain them now. What were you thinking?
You didn't trust the Dark Lords with that power; now they'll never have it.
I kept it away from the Sith.
That much I appreciate. But there are other consequences:
The Star Cabal was devoted to lies and manipulation. The Black Codex was the source of their power.
I'm sick of what it stood for.
Now it's gone. I won't apologize for that.
Clearly not. But there are other consequences:
I found the Black Codex--but so did the Republic. I had to wipe it before they got away.
I'm sorry I had to destroy it.
Damnation.
I couldn't find anything. Maybe the data was deleted. Maybe the archive never existed.
There was nothing there.
Yes. I'm sure they tracked everything by use of a mnemonic.
By the time I could search, the "Black Codex" was gone. It's out there somewhere.
Someone must have taken it.
Not one survivor, but they managed to get their archives to safety. Quite an achievement.
You realize this invites chaos. The conspirators' weapons and resources won't disappear just because the data is gone, and we can't predict who'll obtain them.
Consider the alternative: Putting a thousand years of secrets in the hands of one group would recreate the cabal we destroyed.
A little chaos can be healthy.
Instead, those secrets return to the world from which they were stolen. A sort of justice.
Granted. But there are other consequences:
When the conspirators' legacy does turn up, we'll be waiting. Won't we?
We'll have to be prepared.
Not everything ends in disaster, Minister.
You worry too much.
The present threat is dealt with, I grant you. But there are other consequences:
Imperial Intelligence is not being rebuilt. The secrets were your chance to buy protection; now you'll be branded a renegade working unsanctioned missions.
There will be power struggles. Dark days are coming for the Empire, and I can't protect you.
What do you mean, they're not rebuilding Intelligence?
What are you talking about?
Why should the Sith give power back, when they can remake us?
I've given the Empire everything. Why should I need protection?
I've served loyally.
Without me, the Star Cabal would have won. Without me, the Shadow Arsenal would be in Republic hands!
The Empire needs me!
You and I are a threat to the vision of Sith Intelligence. With luck, I may retire gracefully. Without, I expect to be hanged.
You've committed enough crimes against me. I can do without that help.
I don't need your "protection."
Fair enough. I'll ask the Sith to invite you to my hanging, but a word of advice:
Renegade or not, you will be needed. Don't share my fate.
We've had our disagreements. But I've always respected you.
Thank you for everything, sir.
Your work won't be forgotten.
You still don't really understand. Who I am, what I'm capable of.
You have no idea what I am.
Goodbye, Minister.
Dismissed, agent.
Congratulations are due, but if we're going to track and eliminate the surviving conspirators, I need their secrets. Give the data to me, please.
They called it the Black Codex. It should be what you want.
Here you go.
Yes, indeed.
Tell me, Minister: Why do you really want the Black Codex?
What are you planning?
So that for once in my life, I can do the right thing.
You know, people keep asking for the Black Codex. Frankly, I'm surprised everyone finds it so interesting.
That's a popular request.
I never did like your sense of humor.
Despite all their evils, the Star Cabal did something remarkable. They stayed invisible for centuries, operating independent of the great powers.
In my career, I can hardly scratch my nose without being stymied by a Dark Lord.
Our superiors make service difficult sometimes.
I can sympathize.
With due respect, some people might interpret that the wrong way.
That's dangerous to say aloud.
Then let me be perfectly clear.
I'm well aware that you see the Sith as enemies.
You're afraid of the Sith.
I see them as an obstacle to serving the Empire.
The lives I've destroyed, the atrocities I've approved--all of it was to make the Empire a better place. I failed.
Now I turn to you, and to the Black Codex. Imperial Intelligence is not being rebuilt; you need to escape while you have the chance.
Escape from what? What's happening to Intelligence?
What are you talking about?
The Sith and the military have wanted our resources for years--now that we belong to them, things will change.
How long have you been planning something like this?
You've been plotting awhile...
Since long before I realized our days were numbered.
Why should I escape? You're the one who's scared.
I don't need to do anything.
Damn it, listen to me.
The conspirators erased themselves from history. The Black Codex can help you go dark, destroy all records of your identity.
You would answer to no one--not a new "Sith Intelligence," not superior officers. You'd serve the Empire as a free agent... maybe rediscover your conscience.
You would answer to no one--not a new "Sith Intelligence," not superior officers. You'd serve the Empire as a free agent; exercise that conscience of yours.
Then let's get started.
Even if I escape, what about you and the others?
You want me to abandon ship?
With luck, I may retire gracefully; without, I expect to be hanged. But the others won't be blamed for my mistakes.
They'll be your allies on the inside, while you operate in the shadows. It's the best I can offer.
We have a deal, Minister. I get my freedom, the Empire gets an invisible ally.
All right. Let's do it.
You're putting a lot of trust in me.
You might just regret this.
We use the resources we have.
Activate the Black Codex. Retrieve Imperial security codes and scan for references to agent "Cipher Nine"; eliminate them all.
No more designation. Not even a name--you're a ghost with enough secrets to blackmail the galaxy.
The Empire's going to need you. Someone will be in touch.
I'm sorry, Minister. Your best isn't enough.
Too bad. I won't leave.
Loyal 'til the end. What's coming is dangerous.
I have no interest in "going dark."
I'm not interested.
Very well.
There will be power struggles, and I can't protect you. With luck, I may retire gracefully; without, I expect to be hanged.
But if you want to remain, I wish you well, Cipher, however long that name lasts.
I stood by the Empire as they dismantled Operations. I'll survive whatever they do next.
I'll stay true to my path.
And even if I'm not wanted anymore... I still have work to finish.
However bleak it may seem, we're not finished. I'll make the Empire a better place.
We can reform the Empire.
Not by fleeing. By doing my duty no matter what.
Thank you, agent. Dismissed.
Let the Sith reform our operation. Let them try to change what we do. I look forward to seeing what happens.
I don't run from challenges.
Dismissed, agent. Watch your back.
The Star Cabal awaits you.
You wanted to see me, Minister?
Yes, come in.
This ship and crew were gifts from Darth Jadus. Distracted as he may be, he isn't entirely out of the picture.
I suppose I should thank you. The Star Cabal ruined us quite thoroughly.
Leave the thanks for later and tell me what we've learned.
Let's focus on the job.
Last I was aware, Lord Jadus had gone into seclusion.
You've heard from Jadus?
Where he remains. I expect he allowed the dismantling of Operations--lull the enemy into a sense of security.
What happened was your responsibility. You should have been prepared.
You let them dismantle us!
I stretched my influence as far as I could. Pushing harder would only have guaranteed your colleagues reassignment as cannon fodder.
Last we talked, I sent you to hunt "invisible agents" manipulating the war. How did that mission turn out?
It was more complicated than expected. It's been a while, sir.
Not perfectly, to be honest.
Indeed. Welcome back from your tour of duty. I've spent my time calling in favors.
Sir. The ship, the crew--this is your doing?
Keeper said you arranged this?
Officially, I'm under house arrest in Kaas City--but even with the demise of Intelligence, certain Moffs owe me favors.
Now we face a conspiracy as old as the Emperor, and nearly as powerful. Pity we have to destroy it.
Keeper thinks we're on the edge of victory. What's our status?
I'm ready to go.
This war is meant to wipe us out. Remove the Jedi and Sith, Republic and Empire, and start over.
They want to rule the galaxy.
Yes--but spies cannot be zealots. That is their weakness.
They tried to ruin me. They did ruin Intelligence and they hurt our people.
You want revenge; so do I.
Along with our Watchers, Ardun Kothe's victims, the people of Isen Four--there will never be an accounting.
Your work on Corellia allowed us to trace the conspirators' communications to a space station in the Null Zone.
The mission went sour. The conspirators struck back, and the man appointed to protect us did nothing.
You failed Intelligence.
I did what I could. This ship and its crew represent the last of favors owed to me.
But while Intelligence may be gone, your work on Corellia let us trace the conspirators' communications to a space station in the Null Zone.
We believe that station to be their base of operations.
How do we make our approach?
What's the plan of attack?
What do we know about it? Size, specifications.
Tell me about their base.
Based on its hyperwave silhouette, it could pass as a deep space refueling post. But its energy readings are masked.
They've lured us into traps before.
It could be a hoax.
Not this time--they finally slipped, and we knew what to look for.
I want you to take your team there immediately; any delay, and we risk the enemy escaping.
Eliminate any members of the inner circle present, and obtain their records--the names of their followers, their resources, and every black project they've co-opted.
Search, destroy and retrieve. What about conspirators who aren't aboard?
Straightforward enough.
You have plans for the information?
Why do you want the records?
Operations Division was disbanded. I don't take orders from you.
You're not my boss anymore.
You may have lost your authority--but I haven't. Watch your tone.
You don't give me orders.
Consider me the voice of experience.
With the Star Cabal's secrets, we can scour the galaxy for what's left of their membership. Otherwise, they'll soon regroup.
Of course, the conspirators' secrets have other uses. Once this crisis passes, the Sith will want them in safe hands.
Safe hands. Of course.
I understand your meaning.
The conspirators used their secrets to blackmail, to brainwash--to disappear.
What "other uses," exactly?
I'm certain my lord will appreciate your consideration.
They will belong to Jadus.
Cipher, I regret a great deal about our relationship. I put you in a place no one should be, and wiped my hands of you just as quickly.
I let others repeat my mistakes, and I let them steal your mind.
But consider one thing: If you could change who you've become, would you take that opportunity?
What the Sith want, we must provide.
It is our duty to serve.
Cipher--when I began at Intelligence, I saw it as a distraction from my military career. Eventually, I grew to accept my role.
I developed goals in place of ideals, and I found ways to achieve those goals. I hoped authority would help me effect change.
But for us, there are limits to what authority can do.
Ship's overhaul is finished, sir--she'll get to the station out of sight.
Ship's overhaul is finished, sir--he'll get to the station out of sight.
The operation begins. Stop the conspirators, and take back everything they've stolen.
You have my word.
I will stop them.
If you have something to say to me, Minister, be direct.
Wait--what were you saying?
You heard the call. Your ship is waiting.
You're the man who authorized my brainwashing. Don't give me advice, and don't ask for help.
You have a lot to answer for.
Understood. Your ship is waiting.
I'm very busy, thank you.
